You better google the word volatility - it does not relate to the value or level of the market. Volatility is a statistical measure of the dispersion of returns for a given security or market index

@realmoney Mar 11, 2020 | 03:08 PM EDT DOUG KASS A Few Words of Reflection in Rough Times Over the last few weeks, I have tried to communicate with transparency, honesty and analysis on my views on the market, sectors and individual stocks. I have tried to have a steady

hand and an active pen in the face of the unprecedented market volatility and growing uncertainties. Running money and writing have been difficult in this period -- as personal stress that accumulates in such emotional times. In a way it feels almost like 9/11 (during and after

) but with a different context. Back then, our government officials responded deliberately and we all pray that our politicians respond responsibly and coherently in the time ahead. @jimcramer @tomkeene Enjoy the rest of the week, I am outta here.

I am sorry and this is not an ad hominem attack - but the same people that were confidentally bullish in early February are now confidentally bearish. Them the facts. I say they will be wrong at both levels.

Scared Shortless? Its time to look under the market's hood... * When in doubt, trust bonds. While equities are unstable today, the fixed income market is stable - the ten year US note yield is UP by four basis points (and yielding nearly 0.80%). * There are other divergences

, as seen this week in the VIX curve * The coronavirus' impact could fade as soon as six months from now. While I certainly have no scientific edge there, not thinking that's a possibility is a bit narrowminded. * The Federal Reserve will go to zero interest rates and will

probably do even more "liquidity enhancing" ploys (even without further market declines). * President Trump knows that the stock market is a good indicator of his re-election, so he will likely be hellbent on trying to "keep it up." The breadth of the stimulus chatter with an

expanding $1.2 trillion budget deficit and record low unemployment are quite something to behold... didnt this used to be called planning for the worst… or perhaps just using personal savings? But I digress. * A strong majority of the sell side/ talking head universe has gone

from "it's just the flu" to full on bearishness in under 3 weeks & -18% from record highs. I have a feeling the layering on of “hedging” in equities and in high yield could hold the potential for a wicked rally on any real positive corona developments (even weeks from now).

@davidfaber @jimcramer Yesterday Berkshire sold one billion euros for five years and a zero interest rate. I agree with Jimmy, the government should immediately refinance bigly! @carlquintanilliahttps://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1067983/000119312520064645/d853116d424b5.htm

From my opener on @realmoney "This column is about the merits of trading and longer term investing in today's volatile and unpredictable market. In his morning commentary, my pal Rev Shark suggests trading not investing is an appropriate strategy today...

Rev is a brilliant and successful trader - I have watched and read him closely over the years. He views stocks as trading sardines and is often unconcerned about the fundamental merits of a stock. He often trades "shiny objects" successfully even though he fully recognizes
that they might not even exist a year from today. That takes discipline and fundamental dispassion that few traders possess..."

"Dramatic volatility and market unpredictability can provide superior entry levels for long term investors. Be careful trading in the market without memory from day to day (or hour to hour) but be willing to capitalize on unusual longer term entry levels in individual stocks."
Unlike @revshark I believe it is time to both trade and invest opportunistically.
That is not the debate. The debate is whether one should restrict oneself to trading or investing in period of unprecdented volatility. You say trading, I say either. piped.video/watch?v=LOILZ_D3…

The Berkshire Hathaway five year note with no interest is cra cra! sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/… @jimcramer @tomkeene @davidfaber @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @riskreversal @michaelsantoli @carlquintanilla
Read @revshark column yesterday on @realmoney Read my response today - twitter is not place for the debate, too few characters! His view and my view. We are respectful of each others'...

I emphasize in the column that it is not about calling a bottom - its about the merits of opportunistic investing (vs opportunistic trading) in a grossly heightened vol backdrop which turns in an instant.
The question is the merits of trading when moves are 5% in either direction in a few hours - its unpredictable despite the appearance of a downtrend. And I give examples of problems that crop up.

I try to make the case on @realmoney that this is precisely the time to consider investing. You disagree, you think trading is superior in this backdrop of a market without memory from day to day. Though the trend is clearly down (for now) it could change any minute.

No @revshark it is entirely different. I am respectfully reacting to your column that preaches daytrading and not investing in this uber volatile market. I try to explain why unpredictability of moves in short term render trading unusually difficult. Only pros apply.
Unfortunately there exists a double standard in the financial media. There are "teachers pets" who are never questioned about being self confident and wrong. @SquawkCNBC
The most successful longer term investments typically result in short term pain Anthony. Read my article before commenting.

Read my entire column on @realmoney before commenting @revshark! I try to make the point crystal clear. No one knows where the bottom is. That current prices, with a longer term perspective, may provide unusually attractive entry points. Then I discuss difficulty in trading.

longer term investor because it serves up bargain purchases - it also provides some opportunities to the professional trader (but to only those that are quick afoot and disciplined) * So, Rev says trading, I say either! * He likes potato and I like potahto @jimcramer @revshark
